title: 113_s2952
content:
The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives, and the Majority Leader of the Senate. Among the members, there are academic researchers, data experts, individuals with experience in program administration, and those with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives, and the Majority Leader of the Senate. Among the members, expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management is considered. The Senate appoints three members, including academic researchers, data experts, and individuals with experience in program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The President selects the Chairperson and Co-Chairperson. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives, and the Majority Leader of the Senate. Appointments should consider expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management. The Chairperson is selected by the President, and the Co-Chairperson is selected by the Speaker of the House. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members of the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses at authorized rates while performing services for the Commission. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking has duties outlined in Section 4. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and research, modifying infrastructure, and incorporating outcomes measurement. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will study how to modify protocols to fulfill objectives, make recommendations on outcomes measurement, and consider creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. This includes evaluating relevant administrative datasets, linking survey datasets, and identifying legal and administrative barriers. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will study the creation of a potential clearinghouse for program and survey data. This involves evaluating administrative datasets, linking survey datasets, addressing legal and administrative barriers, determining data-sharing infrastructure, funding mechanisms, access for qualified researchers, limitations on data use, privacy protection, and utilizing research results to inform policymakers and program administrators. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions based on their study. The report will address how to protect information, use research results to inform policymakers, and incentivize interagency sharing of information to improve program effectiveness and data accuracy. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will submit a report with recommendations for legislation or administrative actions based on their study findings. The report must be submitted within 15 months of a majority of Commission members being appointed. Administrative data refers to information generated or collected by a Federal agency for program evaluation purposes. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will have specific operations and powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will receive administrative assistance from various government agencies and must hold meetings within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will meet within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members and establish rules of procedure for conducting business, including holding hearings and receiving evidence as needed. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking can hold hearings, contract with government and private agencies, use the United States mails, accept gifts, and be administered by the National Academy of Public Administration. Funding is subject to availability. The Director of the Census will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to administer the Commission. Funding, not to exceed $2,000,000, will be provided by principal statistical agencies at the request of the Director. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL.

The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson and co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services. 

SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
